bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, May 11, 1946

div1.p: Hench thinks that Reed was independent of Sternberg in his yellow fever investigation and is trying to decide how much credit Sternberg deserves. Hench believes that Reed and Lazear worked out the project on their own.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, May 11, 1946
div1.opener:
Y.F.
May 11, 1946
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I believe that I wrote you that I was going east to medical meetings
and will be in Washington for five days. I expect to see General Kean,
General Reed, General Ireland and others. I have been so busy the last
four years that I have had little time indeed to devote to the Yellow
Fever Story. To catch up on unfinished professional work will take me
most of this year. Nevertheless, I do spend a few hours every now and then
trying to check up on unfinished Yellow Fever business.

I recently reviewed my entire correspondence with General Kean and
have made out a questionnaire, a copy of which I enclose. As questions
came to my mind, I wrote them down, but later found that I had answered
them, or in some cases have answers. I have found it extremely valuable
to get the answers in the very words of the person I am interviewing.

Frankly, I have been trying to find time to prepare a somewhat
similar questionnaire for you, with the thought that we might, while I am
in San Francisco, spend a couple of hours together with some public steno-
grapher or other stenographic secretary whom you perhaps might know and let
her take down our conversation, questions and answers. So far I haven't
been able to review my entire correspondence with you and see what unfinish-
ed business I have. At the moment, I am trying to unravel and solve the
problem as to just how independent Reed was in the matter of his Yellow Fever
investigation and whether the Surgeon General actually did (as claims are
made) precisely outline to Reed the lines of investigation to follow. You
know my primary opinion is that Reed and Lazear worked out the details and
that Reed originated the broad outline, independent of Sternberg. Undoubt-
edly Sternberg deserves some credit and I am trying to find out just how
much. Would you kindly look over the enclosed data. When I arrive in San
Francisco, I may have with me General Kean's answers and we can discuss the
whole matter then.

At times it will seem to you that I am asking the same question over
again. In some cases, this is true, as I have had some conflicting answers
or because I have found the answers incomplete. Please forgive me for this
apparent repetitiousness. Incidentally, I apologize for the apparent im-
politeness of my questionnaire where I speak Kean doing this and Reed that.
General Albert E. Truby - 2 - May 11, 1946
My secretary copied it just as I had jotted it down from time to time
and we did not, unfortunately, take the time to smooth it up and make it
polite.

It will be so nice to see you and Mrs. Truby again. I am anxious
to have you meet my wife and visa versa. She is a wonderful person and,
incidentally, this is her forty-first birthday today. We have reserva-
tions at the Mark Hopkins and expect to spend four or five days in the
second week of July at the El Encanto Hotel in Santa Barbara, where I hope
to see the Lazears.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:kw
Enc.
P. S. The above letter of May 11 didn't get sent as I have been
in a tizzy trying to get ready to go East for a month. Meanwhile, your
nice letter of the fourteenth has arrived.
I am very anxious to have you and Mrs. Truby meet Mary. She is
your sort of people and vice versa. We don't want Mrs. Truby to bother
much. Mary has been in San Francisco on several occasions, but by all
means, we must meet and all “get drunk together”! We are fortunate to
have rooms at the Mark Hopkins Hotel. I certainly want to spend part of a
day, if possible a whole day, with you and my thought at the moment would
be that at least we could spend the afternoon together, and if you and Mrs.
Truby would do us the honor of dining with us at the Mark Hopkins, that would
be grand. (Now, don't persuade Mrs. Truby to have us there. I am an old
married man and I know how the ladies of the house love to go out for dinner,
so if it is alright with you, please accept the invitation.) As to the exact
date, could we wait until our arrival?
It will be indeed a pleasure to see General Kean, General Reed
and others on June 2, and should you wish to write me, I will be at the
Statler in Washington at that time.
P.S.H.
